facts.text: This appeal with special leave is directed against a judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta delivered on a reference by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal Calcutta Bench under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, XI of 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal with special leave is directed against a judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta delivered on a reference by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal  Calcutta Bench  under section 66 1

facts.text: The High Court answered the referred question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: of the Indian Income-tax Act  XI of 1922  hereinafter referred to as the Act whereby the High Court answered the referred question in the negative.

facts.text: Prior to November 29, 1928, Steel Bros. Co. Ltd. (Steels) and Ellermans Arracan Rice and Trading Co. Ltd. (Ellermans) carried on trade in Burma rice and/or its by-products in Burma, in London and elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to November 29, 1928, Steel Bros. Co. Ltd.  hereinafter referred to as Steels  and Ellermans Arracan Rice and Trading Co. Ltd.  hereinafter referred to as Ellermans  carried on trade in Burma rice

facts.text: Both Steels and Ellermans had rice milling machines and produced rice from paddy.

anchor.surface_text: and or its by-products in Burma in London and elsewhere inter alia through Burma and London Bullenger Rice Pool and the New General Rice Co. Ltd. Apart from the selling of rice, both these companypanies had rice

facts.text: Burma Co. Ltd. (Burma) had a few rice mills and never purchased paddy or sold rice. All shares of Burma were held by Steels, who were also its managing agents.

anchor.surface_text: There was another companypany known as the Burma Co. Ltd.  hereinafter referred to as Burma . This companypany also had a few rice mills. It never purchased paddy or sold rice. All the shares of this companypany

facts.text: On or about November 29, 1928, an agreement was entered into between Steels, Burma and Ellermans for amalgamated working of Burma rice business.

anchor.surface_text: were held by Steels, who were also its managing agents. On or about November 29, 1928, an agreement was entered into between the Steels, Burma and Ellermans to provide for the amalgamated working of the

facts.text: The combined business was referred to as the Combination.

anchor.surface_text: Burma rice business in Burma and London of all the three companypanies under the management of Steels. The companybined business of Steels, Burma and Ellermans was referred to therein as the Combination.

facts.text: All stocks of Burma rice and by-products at 30th November, 1928, excluded from agreement and remained property of individual owners.

anchor.surface_text: All stocks of Burma rice and by-products in hand at 30th November, 1928, were excluded from this agreement and remained the property of the individual owners to be disposed of by them as they thought fit

facts.text: Entire business in Burma hitherto carried on by Ellermans taken over and managed by Steels as from 1st December, 1928.

anchor.surface_text: and the entire business in Burma hitherto carried on by Ellermans was to be taken over and managed by Steels as from 1st December, 1928, and companyducted from Steelsoffices in London, Rangoon and

facts.text: Profit or loss of Combination shared between Steels/Burma and Ellermans in ratios: Rangoon 68:32, Bassein 68:32, Akyab 68:32, Moulmein 72:28.

anchor.surface_text: The profit or loss of the business of the Combination carried on at the under mentioned places was to be shared by and divided between Steels and Ellermans in the following ratios Rangoon Bassein Akyab Moulmein Steels Burma 68 68 68 72 Ellermans 32 32 32 28

facts.text: Rice mills of Burma (Burma Upper Kanungtoe Mill in Rangoon, Burma Mill in Bassein, Burmas Martaban Mill in Moulmein) to be worked by Steels for Combination.

anchor.surface_text: The rice mills belonging to Burma, viz., Burma Upper Kanungtoe Mill in Rangoon, Burma Mill in Bassein and Burmas Martaban Mill in Moulmein, were to be worked by the Steels for the purpose of the Combination  clause 4a .

facts.text: Agreement effective from 1st December, 1928, terminable on 30th November, 1930 or subsequent by notice not later than preceding 1st August.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement was to take effect as from 1st December, 1928, and companyld be terminated on 30th November, 1930, or on any subsequent 30th November, by and party giving numberice to that effect to others number later than the preceding 1st August  clause 12 .

facts.text: Agreement signed by Steels and Ellermans (common seals affixed) and by James Kilgour Michie for and on behalf of Burma.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement was signed and the companymon seals of Steels and Ellermans were affixed thereto and it was also signed by one James Kilgour Michie for and on behalf of Burma.

facts.text: For assessment years 1943-44 and 1944-45, the Combination (assessee) applied to ITO under section 26A for registration of partnership constituted of Steels and Ellermans.

anchor.surface_text: In companynection with the assessments for the assessment years 1943-44 and 1944-45 the Combination  which is hereinafter referred to as the assessee  made applications to the Income-tax Officer under section 26A of the Act for registration of their partnership said to be companystituted of Steels and Ellermans.

facts.text: Applications signed by Steels and Ellermans only, supported by copy of agreement dated November 29, 1928.

anchor.surface_text: These applications were signed by the Steels and Ellermans only and were supported by a companyy of the agreement dated November 29, 1928, which was relied upon as the instrument of partnership of which registration was sought.

facts.text: ITO refused registration by orders dated March 19, 1948 and March 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By two separate orders dated March 19, 1948, and March 31, 1949, the Income-tax Officer, District V, Calcutta, refused registration of the partnership on the ground  i  that the partnership was number

facts.text: ITO grounds: partnership constituted of three parties (Steels, Ellermans, Burma), deed did not specify shares of three; loss not properly allocated.

anchor.surface_text: companystituted of Steels and Ellermans only but was companystituted of those two parties and a third party, viz, Burma, and that the partnership deed did number specify the shares of the said three partners and  ii  that the loss arising during the previous year had number been properly allocated proportionately to the said three partners

facts.text: AAC upheld ITO orders: application signed by two partners but deed showed three; shares of Steels and Burma not shown separately.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee carried an appeal before the Second Additional Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, A Range, Calcutta, who upheld the orders of the Income-tax Officer on the grounds that the application for registration was signed by two partners, Steels and Ellermans, whereas the partnership deed showed that it was a partnership of three partners and that the individual shares of Steels and Burma were number shown separately.

facts.text: ITAT by order dated 20th February, 1951 held partnership really between Steels and Ellermans; Burma 100% subsidiary of Steels.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred an appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal  Calcutta Bench  and by its order dated the 20th February, 1951, the Tribunal held that although the agreement entered number into on November 29, 1928, showed that the three companypanies would carry on the whole of their Burma rice business on amalgamation, on an examination of the agreement it would appear that the companypanies which formed the partnership were really Steels and Ellermans

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal (respondent) applied; ITAT referred question to High Court under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: Upon the application of the Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal  the respondent herein , the Tribunal stated a case and referred the following question of law to the High Court for its decision under section 66 1  of the Act

facts.text: Referred question: Whether Tribunal right in holding partnership between Steels and Ellermans only.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a proper companystruction of the deed of agreement dated 29th November, 1928, and having regard to the relevant facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holing that the partnership was really between Steels and Ellermans and that, therefore, registration should have been allowed under section 26A

facts.text: High Court answered question in negative: partnership of three companies.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by the High Court and the High Court answered the referred question in the negative. The High Court was of the opinion that on a true companystruction and effect of the agreement and particularly having regard to the recital in the agreement and the provisions companytained in clauses 1, 3 a , 12 and 14, thereof, the partnership was a partnership of the three companypanies

facts.text: Assessee applied for certificate under s.66A(2), refused by HC; obtained special leave from Supreme Court under art.136.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee applied for a certificate of fitness under section 66A 2  of the Act which was, however, refused by the High Court with the result that the assessee applied for and obtained from this companyrt special leave to appeal under article 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds: on true construction, Burma was a partner along with Steels and Ellermans.

anchor.surface_text: On a true companystruction of the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, we have, therefore companye to the companyclusion that Burma was a partner along with Steels and Ellermans in the Combination and had a joint share with the Steels in the profit or loss of the Combination.

Section 26A of the Act provides Application may be made to the Income-tax Officer on behalf of any firm, constituted under an instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners, for registration for the purposes of this Act and of any other enactment for the time being in force relating to income-tax or super-tax. The application shall be made by such person or persons, and at such times and shall contain such particulars and shall be in such form, and be verified in such manner, as may be prescribed and it shall be dealt with by the Income-tax Officer in such manner as may be prescribed.

concepts.interpretation: Application must be signed by all partners and specify individual shares of all partners; otherwise ITO cannot entertain or register.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2 of the Indian Income-tax Rules, 1922, prescribes Any firm constituted under in instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners may, under the provisions of section 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, Such application shall be signed by all the partners (not being minors) personally, or in the case of a dissolved firm by all persons (not being minors) who were partners in the firm immediately before dissolution and by the legal representative of any such partner who is deceased

concepts.interpretation: Application for registration shall be signed by all the partners.

issues.text: Whether on a proper construction of the deed of agreement dated 29th November, 1928, and having regard to the relevant facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the partnership was really between Steels and Ellermans and that, therefore, registration should have been allowed under section 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a proper construction of the deed of agreement dated 29th November, 1928, and having regard to the relevant facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holing that the partnership was really between Steels and Ellermans and that,

issues.text: The sole question that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether on a proper construction of the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, and having regard to the facts and circumstances of the case the applications by the assessee for the registration of the partnership showing Steels and Ellermans as the only partners thereof with their specific shares set out as against each of them and signed only by them were rightly refused by the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether on a proper construction of the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, and having regard to the facts and circumstances of the case the applications by the assessee for the registration of the partnership showing Steels and Ellermans as the only partners thereof with their specific shares set out as against each of them and signed only by them were rightly refused by the Income-tax Officer.

issues.text: The question, therefore, that falls to be determined is whether under the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, Steels and Ellermans who were the signatories to the applications for registration were the only two partners in the Combination or there was also a third partner along with them, viz., Burma, which even though it was a party to the agreement had no individual share specified in the profit or loss of the Combination.

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, that falls to be determined is whether under the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, Steels and Ellermans who were the signatories to the applications for registration were the only two partners in the Combination or there was also a third partner along with them, viz., Burma, which even though it was a party to the agreement had no individual share specified in the profit or loss of the Combination.

arguments.claim: The partnership was constituted of three parties: Steels, Ellermans, and Burma, and the partnership deed did not specify the shares of the three partners.

arguments.claim: Although the agreement showed three companies, the companies which formed the partnership were really Steels and Ellermans; Burma, a 100% subsidiary of Steels, had hardly anything to do with the Combination.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC holds textual construction of agreement paramount; facts do not detract from three-partner conclusion.

arguments.claim: On true construction of agreement, particularly recital and clauses 1, 3(a), 12, 14, the partnership was of three companies; applications not made by three, deed did not specify shares, so registration rightly refused.

arguments.claim: Burma was not a partner; facts show: (i) all shares of Burma owned by Steels, (ii) Burma never purchased paddy or sold rice, (iii) no share of profits paid to Burma, (iv) Burma's earnings only milling hire from Steels.

anchor.surface_text: The facts and circumstances which were thus sought to be relied upon by the appellant were (i) that all the shares of Burma were owned by the Steels, (ii) that according to the findings of the Tribunal Burma never purchased paddy or sold rice, (iii) that no share of the profits of the Combination had ever been paid to or received by Burma and (iv) that in the carrying out of the agreement the only earnings of Burma had been by way of milling hire paid by Steels to Burma.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: artners, viz., Steels and Ellermans. There is number the slightest doubt whatever that Burma was a partner with Steels and Ellermans in the business o

arguments.court_reasoning: These facts do not detract from partnership conclusion; explained by subsidiary relationship and internal arrangements.

arguments.claim: Agreement entered between three parties (Steels, Burma, Ellermans); clauses show combined business of three, profit/loss shared (Steels/Burma joint vs Ellermans), binding on all three, restrictions on all three, termination by any party, disputes by arbitration, intent to work jointly.

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, we find in the first instance that it is an agreement entered between three parties, viz., Steels, Burma and Ellermans... The clauses of the agreement hereinabove set out would, if there was nothing more, spell out a partnership between the Steels, Burma and Ellermans.

arguments.claim: Relationship is partnership under s4 Partnership Act 1932 or s239 Contract Act: agree to share profits of business carried by all or any for all; combine property, labour, skill.

anchor.surface_text: The relationship which has been brought into existence between the three parties is a relationship between partners who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all within the meaning of the definition of partnership given in section 4 of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932. Even if the definition of partnership which was contained at the relevant date in section 239 of the Indian Contract Act

arguments.claim: Rights conferred on Ellermans but not Burma do not negate Burma's partnership; Burma subsidiary of Steels, no conflict, Steels protect Burma's interests; superfluous to give Burma separate rights.

anchor.surface_text: It is however pointed out on behalf of the appellant that there are several clauses in the agreement which confer rights on Ellermans which rights are not conferred on Burma... It has, however, to be noted that Burma was a subsidiary company of the Steels... The Ellermans on the other hand were strangers... It was not necessary... to provide any special rights... in favour of Burma

arguments.claim: Clause 3(a) brackets Steels/Burma for joint share vs Ellermans; as between Steels/Burma, no further distribution needed as profits to Burma go to Steels anyway; Steels receive joint share.

anchor.surface_text: If this position is borne in mind the provision in clause 3a of the agreement also is easy to understand. So far as the partnership was concerned a joint share between Steels and Burma was reserved by bracketing Steels and Burma together... These ratios were also suggestive as providing roughly two shares between the Steels and Burma bracketed together and one share for the Ellermans

arguments.claim: Burma had rights: terminate (cl12), arbitrate disputes, share profit/loss, agency by Steels; all ingredients of partnership satisfied; not hybrid document.

anchor.surface_text: On a true construction of the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, we have, therefore come to the conclusion that Burma was a partner along with Steels and Ellermans in the Combination and had a joint share with the Steels in the profit or loss of the Combination. It was entitled to terminate the partnership... It had also a right to refer all the disputes... Thus all the ingredients of partnership were satisfied

arguments.claim: Petitioner's relied facts do not detract: shares ownership explains no separate rights; no paddy/rice by Burma as contributed property; no direct profit payment/internal arrangement; milling hire internal.

anchor.surface_text: Adverting to these facts and circumstances, we find that there is nothing in them which runs counter to the conclusion which we have reached above. The fact that all the shares of Burma were owned by the Steels really explains why Burma was not given any specific rights... The fact that Burma never purchased paddy or sold rice is also devoid of significance... The circumstance that no share of the profits... has been already explained above.

arguments.claim: s26A and Rule 2 require application signed by all partners specifying individual shares; here not done as Burma partner not signing, no individual share.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question... whether... the applications... showing Steels and Ellermans as the only partners... signed only by them were rightly refused... Section 26A... Rule 2... In order that an application... it is necessary that the application should be signed by all the partners... Unless that is done it would not be competent...

holdings.text: Burma was a partner along with Steels and Ellermans in the Combination and had a joint share with the Steels in the profit or loss of the Combination.

anchor.surface_text: On a true construction of the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, we have, therefore come to the conclusion that Burma was a partner along with Steels and Ellermans in the Combination and had a joint share with the Steels in the profit or loss of the Combination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction of agreement: entered by three parties, joint p/l sharing (Steels/Burma bracketed), rights to terminate/arbitrate/disputes, agency by Steels, fits partnership definitions; subsidiary status and internal arrangements do not negate.

holdings.text: The applications by the assessee for the registration of the partnership showing Steels and Ellermans as the only partners thereof with their specific shares set out as against each of them and signed only by them were rightly refused by the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether on a proper construction of the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, and having regard to the facts and circumstances of the case the applications by the assessee for the registration of the partnership showing Steels and Ellermans as the only partners thereof with their specific shares set out as against each of them and signed only by them were rightly refused by the Income-tax Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since Burma is third partner, applications not signed by all partners and do not specify individual shares of all, violating s26A and Rule 2.

holdings.text: In order that an application for registration be entertained by the Income-tax Officer and the partnership registered for the purpose of the Act, it is necessary that the application should be signed by all the partners of the firm and should specify the individual shares of the partners. Unless that is done it would not be competent to the Income-tax Officer to entertain the application and it would not be obligatory upon him to register the partnership for the purpose of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In order that an application for registration be entertained by the Income-tax Officer and the partnership registered for the purpose of the Act, it is necessary that the application should be signed by all the partners of the firm and should specify the individual shares of the partners. Unless that is done it would not be competent to the Income-tax Officer to entertain the application and it would not be obligatory upon him to register the partnership for the purpose of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of text of s26A requiring instrument specifying individual shares and Rule 2 requiring all partners to sign.

holdings.text: The relationship which has been brought into existence between the three parties is a relationship between partners who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all within the meaning of the definition of partnership given in section 4 of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement terms show profit-sharing, mutual agency, business carried jointly; matches statutory definition.

holdings.text: Thus all the ingredients of partnership were satisfied and it is futile to urge that the agreement was a hybrid document which was a tripartite agreement so far as the business of the Combination was concerned and was a partnership agreement only between two partners, viz., Steels and Ellermans.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether on a proper construction of the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, and having regard to the facts and circumstances of the case the applications by the assessee for the registration of the partnership showing Steels and Ellermans as the only partners thereof with their specific shares set out as against each of them and signed only by them were rightly refused by the Income-tax Officer.

On a true construction of the agreement dated 29th November, 1928, we have, therefore, come to the conclusion that Burma was a partner along with Steels and Ellermans in the Combination and had a joint share with the Steels in the profit or loss of the Combination. It was entitled to terminate the partnership by giving

anchor.surface_text: In order that an application for registration be entertained by the Income-tax Officer and the partnership registered for the purpose of the Act, it is necessary that the application should be signed by all the partners of the firm and should specify the individual shares of the partners. Unless that is done it would not be competent to the Income-tax Officer to entertain the application and it would not be obligatory upon him to register the partnership for the purpose of the Act.
